title: Volkswagen cheated emissions tests in Europe, says German Minister
text:
Volkswagen cheated emissions tests in Europe, says German Minister Volkswagen cheated emissions tests in Europe, says German Minister DISGRACED car maker Volkswagen manipulated official pollution tests in Europe, as well as the US, the German Transport Minister confirmed today, as the emissions scandal deepened. PUBLISHED: 12:32, Thu, Sep 24, 2015 | UPDATED: 13:54, Thu, Sep 24, 2015 GETTY Volkswagen manipulated emissions tests in Europe, said the German minister 
Alexander Dobrindt said it was unclear how many vehicles in Europe were implicated but that cars with 1.6 and 2.0 litre engines were among those affected. He also said that random tests are to be carried out on cars that are not manufactured by Volkswagen amid fears that deceiving authorities is an industry-wide practice. Mr Dobrindt "We have been informed that also in Europe, vehicles with 1.6 and 2.0 litre diesel engines are affected by the manipulations that are being talked about." Related articles Volkswagen boss Martin Winterkorn resigns over emissions scandal 
He added: "It is clear that the Federal Office for Motor Traffic will not exclusively concentrate on the VW models in question but that it will also carry out random tests on vehicles made by other carmakers." 
Volkswagen has admitted that around 11million of its cars worldwide have been fitted with software that allows them to deceive their way through emissions tests. 
The US Environmenal Protection Agency (EPA) found that during normal driving cars were up to 40 times over official pollution limits. 
Around half a million cars are to be recalled in the US, and it's expected that millions more will be called back in Britain and Europe . AP German Finance Minister, Alexander Dobrindt PA Volkswagen chief executive Martin Winterkorn has resigned 
German regulators have now urged the manufacturer to move quickly to either compensate drivers with affected cars or retrofit the vehicles. 
Klaus Mueller, head of the Federation of German Consumer Organisations, said: "To regain confidence, Volkswagen needs to indemnify any consumers affected by damage.""The company must either retrofit all affected vehicles or give the affected individuals the right to retrofitting." PA Volkswagen cars have been cheating emission tests 
Yesterday the firm's chief executive Martin Winterkorn resigned over the crisis, but implied that he had not been aware of the deceit by adding that there had been "no wrong doing" on his part. 
He said: "I am stunned that misconduct on such a scale was possible in the Volkswagen Group." 
Two of Volkswagen group's highest-ranking engineers will also be forced to quit, according to reports. 
The German group has set aside almost £5bn (€6.5bn) euros to pay for the crisis, but it's expected to cost far more. Related articles
